titleStmt.title: Newes from Wales or, The Prittish Parliament. Called, and assembled upon many cood reasons and considerations, and for the benefit of her countries to secure them from her round-head, long-tayld enemies, by the crave and politick wisdoms of her prittish purgesses. With many other pusinesses, projects and purposes, tending to the relief of her Prittish Commons, and the honour and reputations of her country of Wales. Newly sent up py her trusty and welpeloved cousin the Welch empassadour, to give all the world notice of her purpose, to call a Welch Parliament. And lately her manifold grievances hereunto joyned and annexed. Written py her loving cousin and well-willer Morgan Loyd.
titleStmt.author: Loyd, Morgan.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 14 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 5 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: Newes from Wales or, The Prittish Parliament. Called, and assembled upon many cood reasons and considerations, and for the benefit of her countries to secure them from her round-head, long-tayld enemies, by the crave and politick wisdoms of her prittish purgesses. With many other pusinesses, projects and purposes, tending to the relief of her Prittish Commons, and the honour and reputations of her country of Wales. Newly sent up py her trusty and welpeloved cousin the Welch empassadour, to give all the world notice of her purpose, to call a Welch Parliament. And lately her manifold grievances hereunto joyned and annexed. Written py her loving cousin and well-willer Morgan Loyd.

notesStmt.note: A political satire and parody of Welsh dialect.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: NEWES FROM WALES OR, THE PRITTISH PARLIAMENT.

CALLED, And a≈ø≈øembled upon many cood Rea≈øons and Con≈øiderations, and for the benefit of her Countries to ≈øecure them from her Round-head, Long-tayld Enemies, by the crave and politick wi≈ødoms of her Pritti≈øh Purge≈ø≈øes.
With many other Pu≈øine≈ø≈øes, Projects and Purpo≈øes, tending to the Relief of her Pritti≈øh Commons, and the Honour and Reputations of her Country of Wales.
Newly ≈øent up py her tru≈øty and welpeloved Cou≈øin the Welch Empa≈ø≈øadour, to give all the World Notice of her purpo≈øe, to call a Welch Parliament.
And lately her manifold Grievances hereunto joyned and annexed.
Written py her loving Cou≈øin and Well-willer Morgan Loyd.

div.head: The Welch Parliament.
div.p:
HEr Countries of Wales peing te ancient Nurceries and habitations of the true Pritti≈øh plood, a≈øcending from old anticke Families, having to her creat di≈øgrace received many affronts, indignities, and injuries from her cunning enemies, e≈øpecially from that Ra≈øcall, Repellious Rogue or Round-head Robin Little-eyes; and having in due and ha≈øtie con≈øiderations thereof penned and publi≈øhed her Declarations, Complaints, and Petitions, together with her Prote≈øtations, in hope to have good an≈øwers and ≈øatisfaction thereunto; and contrary (looke you) to her expectations, have to her further reproaches received nothing put contumelies and diri≈øions, and no orders taken for the peating out neither with Cuns, Pikes, nor long Pills, her long-tayl'd enemies, who make her countries poore and peggarly, to the con≈øtruction and ruine of her Coods and undoing of her wifes and ≈øhildren: Her plood peing therefore very hot, and her heads full of learned knowledges in all points and politick pu≈øine≈ø≈øes, and having creat under≈øtandings, and many quick piting griefes in her po≈øome, her is in the names and appellations of all her ≈øhires and their mountaines, purpo≈øed to di≈ø≈øemble and call a creat and crave company of Pritti≈øh Purge≈ø≈øes, who ≈øitting in her cray apparels and long Hookes in her hands ≈øhall lay apout them in judicature and ≈øentences, and ≈øhall make the creat Malefactors and defenders with te ≈ømall eyes to
runne into puni≈øhments, and not tare to appeare before their pold pritti≈øh faces di≈ø≈øembled and gathered together on one of the Welch Mountaines, in manners and fa≈øhions (though a farre off) like unto a Parliament, and then her will among≈øt her owne com ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ men and co≈øen Purge≈ø≈øes find re≈øpects and favours, and have all her Pills and Petitions not with≈øtanding their bad orthographies and Engli≈øh enditings read to the end, and beyond the end, and more revenges, botes and ≈øhudgements pa≈øt and repa≈øt upon her Round-headed Long-tayld Enemies then her out of her cood natures and compa≈ø≈øions can de≈øire. And ≈øome part of her Countries and the Pritti≈øh Ocean being in pro≈øpects and ≈øights & very neer unto Ireland, where it may be ≈øuppo≈øed, that py the running away of Rebels, creat pieces of pred and ≈øchee≈øe have for ha≈øt dropt out of their knap≈øacks; whereby her Long tayld enemies have bin ready to fall on, it is therefore thought fit in her pritti≈øh wi≈ødoms, that her Countrymen ≈øhould be ready at morning, noon and nightwith creat watches in Sea-towns, to peat her enemies, if they ≈øhould out of their cruell ≈øtomacks come in creat troops come upon planks or poords of ≈øhips, ≈øwiming over her pritti≈øh Seas, with purpo≈øes to land in Wales, and this he do purpo≈øe ≈øhall fir≈øt pe concluded and agreed uPon in the pritti≈øh Parliament. He do next mean though her pur≈øes pe not ≈øo p ‚Ä¢ g, yet her have hands cods plutter a nails and arms too, and therfore he will not pe put into fears with her creat huge high Mountains, put he do purpo≈øe to make to make Taxations and Ea≈øments upon all her ≈øhires and lay on ≈øilver two pences upon all her cuntry-mans heads & pates, and with cood moneys as her have contriv'd and plotted the pu≈øine≈ø≈øes and ≈øharges to a farthing, her will make all her mountains wheron her Coats, ≈øheeps, Rvnts, do take bare Commons together, to be as plain as her table in her hou≈øe, and this her will pring to defears and purpo≈øes, with her ≈øhovels and her ≈øpades and all her poys ≈øhal work till her proud mountains pe turned into creen middows, that ≈øo her cows &
coats may fill their pellies, and make her creater ≈øtore of putter and ≈øhee≈øe, than ever was in any lnowledge or memory in Wales, And wheras her poor tenants in her Countties are forced to pay creat ≈øtore of Rents for her poor Cottages, her mu≈øt al≈øo pay ≈øhillings and pence to her Shentries and Landlords, her will have therfore publique laws contrived in goodfa≈øhions, that her may dwel in pig hou≈øes, and pe not ≈øubject to ≈øell her Cows at her markets, to her great hinderances and lo≈ø≈øes, to make monies for ≈øuch unrea≈øonable and prvti≈øh payments, put that her may pay two pennies yearly, according as it was in the dais of King Arthur, a creat while ago, and not be found to run away in her old apparels up to Loudon, to hide her ≈øelf from her Country-man Landlord. He is al≈øo re≈øolved, that this ≈øhall be al≈øo taken into con≈øiderations and con≈øultations in the Pritti≈øh Parliament. He is al≈øo very angry, and in great Furies, again≈øt her pabling Countrywoman of hers, that whe her is in her rages any where, and do out of her bloud ≈øwear by S. Taffie her will in ≈øimilitudes and imitations an≈øwer her again with polices and repetitions, and cry S. Tavy, then if her ca≈øt her looks into admirations apout her, & if her ask what pooby is that, that makes her in the pryars, her will ≈øay what pooby is that, then if her ≈øay come out if her dare for her nails, her will ≈øay if her dare for her nails, and when her after much mole≈øtations of mind enquir'd and asked the que≈øtions of Sir ≈øenkins the Curate of her pari≈øh, concerning the affronts, and what welch Divels han ted the vds, he made his re≈øolutions and definitions, that it was her puling Countrey-womens Echoes, as he cals her, who had in the ≈øtony powels and pellies of the mountains, Her wil therfore make her humble ≈øuits, that this welch ≈øhe lived gen Echoes by names and ≈øurnames may pe puni≈øhed out of her vds and mountains, cau≈øe her hath ≈øo often ≈øtird up her pritti≈øh plonds with hermow and ≈øheers, & her could never in all her dais have a blow at her crowns with her long welch hooks, for if her culd
her wuld have cut her tongues out of her heads, for mocking her Cuntry wen, but cau≈øe her is her unknown cuntry woman the fore her will put in ≈øtrange Articles and Inditements again≈øt this Tivell in the uds, that ≈øo her priti≈øh Parliament m ‚Ä¢ y rake Order to puni≈øh the pawling tongue of Mrs. Nobodies, or Mrs. Echoes as they call her. There is al≈øo a kind of fellows in leather tublets & plew priches, that when her pring her cood peas, parly, Oat, & pread corn to crind at her mil; was never hone≈øt man, put co≈øen her in the mea≈øures of her parly & other corns, her will de≈øire her pritti≈øh Parliament either to turn her out of her mils in her cuntries, or make her hone≈øt if her can or hang her on the mountains. And wheras in her countries there are apundance of very plea≈øant prooks & River, and was creat ≈øtore of cood fi≈øh in them, the priti≈øh Parliament ≈øhall make laws and ≈øtatutes for the cood of her Common-wealths and Countries, that Red-Herrings with pels apout her necks ≈øhall pe put into tho≈øe prooks and Rivers, that her ≈øhenerations may multiply, and with her angle her may go to the prook, and take red herring at her plea≈øure with pels about her neck, and this matter of cood note her welch Parliament was take into her con≈øideration, And moreover wheras many creat Goats take their foods and dyets on the crags and mountains, her was de≈øire her welch Parliament, that cau≈øe her have as long peards as her country man, they may pear Armes as well as her countryman again≈øt her ≈øoe, with Roundheads, and ≈ømall eyes, tho≈øe putter and thee≈øe eaters, and in dangerus occa≈øions, pecsme ≈øouldiers in definces of her countries of Wales. There was moreover a prown politick enemies, that with much cruelties ≈øuck the plood, and eat the pones of her ≈øheeps and young lambs, and do much oppre≈ø≈øions, and then ≈ølip into the vds, and hide her ≈øelves in habitations under th ‚Ä¢ ground, put her welch Parliament ≈øhall put her politick v ‚Ä¢ ≈øhips to tryals, and having found her a plood-≈øucker, ≈øhall if her can, command that all her head may pe cut of on a plock And her welch Parliament ≈øhall make a cood law and order, that when her comes to markets or Fairs,
and fall to pribble prabble with her country man, her may ≈øoundly pa≈øt his pody and preak his crown without fear of being carryed pefo ‚Ä¢ e Shu≈øtice Morgan her co≈øen, to make her appearance for fait and Patteries of her Countryman. And becau≈øe her Pari≈øhes are con≈øi≈øting of a few pighou≈øes out of which a little ≈ømoak doth break forth at the top of ≈øhimneys, and that her Schoolma≈øters have put poor & peggerly pen≈øions, for her In≈øtructions of her shildren, he was therfore in intention to de≈øire her welch Parliament to give her childs Tutors and Schoolma≈øters tens. more yearly for to pay her pooks reparre's, and other cood nece≈ø≈øaries, than ≈øo her children may learn to make petter Orthographies, then her Fore-fathers, and not put up deri≈øion for her pad-Engli≈øh. And moreover her Parliaments ≈øhall provide that there was be more cood Leeks ≈øowd in peds to wear in her Monmouth Caps upon St. Taffies tay, and that none ≈øhall mock her for her cu≈øtoms and fa≈øhions in doing ≈øo, in adorations of her cood codly countryman. And that if her rice or co a wooing to her co≈øen ap Ienkins, or her co≈øen ap Williams daughter out of meere amours and affections, and with her cood actions and playing on her Welch Harpes doe get ‚Ä¢ er in tunes and matrimonies, and doe happen afterward to like petter of her co≈øen Powels daughter and heire to awle her lands and coods, her Welch Parliament ≈øhall allow her to have a paire of wives as well as a paire of poots, that her may commit Matrimonies with the one for affections, and with the other for her creat and rich portions, and not be hanged on ≈øhibbits for her cood wills And her will al≈øo ≈øue unto her parliament, that her may have Cr ‚Ä¢ n≈øtones in awle Townes and creat Corporations, to ‚Ä¢ tind and make ≈øharp her tongues welch pills, that they may cut her enemies into ≈øhips and ≈ømall pieces, and de≈øend her lands and coods and awle her countries again≈øt her pragging foes, that would invade her pounds, marches and Territories of Wales. And that if any of her poor co≈øen or countrey men doe through nece≈ø≈øities, wants, and poverties,
≈øteal or porrow of her next Neighbours, any cow, ≈øheepe, coat, or pea≈øt, and be apprehended for felonies, her ≈øhall py ≈øtatutes of Parliament not pe put to her pook becau≈øe her is pad reader of Engli≈øh Pooks and languages. Put as for points and crounds of Religions, her care not for entring into ≈øuch creat di≈øputations, put her doe with all her Papi≈øts in her countries were pani≈øhed, that her might as true Prote≈øtants live on her lands in creat honours and Reputations, and her will bee alwayes readie with pills and hookes to peat downe papi≈øts in awle her countries, and ≈øpend her be≈øt plood to maintaine the cood Go≈øpels, and that her ≈øelf is true Prittain and ancient ≈øhen, tlemen of Wales, as it ≈øhall be recorded in the Welch parliament which we call from the top of the Mountaines that her co≈øen ap Lewes, her co≈øen ap Griffeth in the Vale, her co≈øen ap Thomas, ap Iones, ap David, ap Williams, ap Morgan, ap Powel, and ap Iinken, with awle their other ur≈øhips in Wales, may upon the mountains in creat ha≈øte & expeditions meet as Purges of the welch Parliament.

list.head: The Pu≈øine≈ø≈øes and con≈øiderations of the welch Parliament are the≈øe.
list.item: THat cood watch may be kept in Sea-towns, to prevent the landing of the long tayl'd enemies.
To lay two pennies on all her Country mans heads, for her Mountains with her ∆≤illages.
That her may pay ≈ømall Rents to her priti≈øh Landlords.
That Red-herrings with pills apout her necks may pe put into prooks and Rivers, to make creat generations.
That coats with as long peards as her country man, may pear Arms again≈øt her foes and enemies.
That all her politick plood-≈øucking Foxes heads may bee cut off on a plock.
That ber may preak her country mans pate at market, and not pe troubled for ≈øalt and patterie.
That Schcolma≈øters may have yearly 10. s. pen≈øions more to puy her pooks.
